channel.title: Azure Login stage

item.title: Azure Login stage
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“frozon566, post:1, topic:427886”]So this is the final block of code in the login.java on the azure base im studying, i believe its for setting up the username and passwords to whatever you chose, basically creating the user

[quote] // Read the user authentication.
in.readInt(); // Skip the user ID.
String username = in.readString();
String password = in.readString();
player.setUsername(username);
player.setPassword(password);
player.setUsername(NameUtil.uppercaseFirstLetter(player.getUsername()));
player.login();
player.setLoginStage(LoginStages.LOGGED_IN);
break;[/quote]

anyways my question is shouldn’t this be checked first like to see if the username is in use before creating? Or is this done somewhere else(idk where this is from the login.java so that would just be weird ), what do you think?[/quote]

The base is probably bare so that developers can add whatever authentication they want in the future, instead of making them conform to whichever is shipped with the server.

Read full topic

item.title: Azure Login stage
item.dc:creator: @frozon566 frozon566
item.description:
@frozon566 wrote:

So this is the final block of code in the login.java on the azure base im studying, i believe its for setting up the username and passwords to whatever you chose, basically creating the user

// Read the user authentication. in.readInt(); // Skip the user ID. String username = in.readString(); String password = in.readString(); player.setUsername(username); player.setPassword(password); player.setUsername(NameUtil.uppercaseFirstLetter(player.getUsername())); player.login(); player.setLoginStage(LoginStages.LOGGED_IN); break;

anyways my question is shouldn’t this be checked first like to see if the username is in use before creating? Or is this done somewhere else(idk where this is from the login.java so that would just be weird ), what do you think?

Read full topic
